sen.j: 第10代崇神天皇の皇女豊鍬入姫命の後を継ぎ天照大神の「御杖代（みつえしろ、神の意を受ける依代）」として大和国から伊賀国・近江国・美濃国・尾張国の諸国を経て伊勢国の国に入り、神託により現在地に伊勢神宮を創建したとされる。
sen.e: She succeeded after Toyosukiiribime no Mikoto, Princess of the tenth Emperor Sujin, as 'Mitsueshiro, or yorishiro, which is an object receiving god's will' of Amaterasu Omikami and went through from Yamato Province, Iga Province, Omi Province, Mino Province, Owari Province, and other provinces and entered Ise Province, and is said to have erected Ise Jingu Shrine at present location by an oracle.

She succeeded Toyosukiiribime no Mikoto, the daughter of the tenth Emperor, Sujin, as the 'Mitsueshiro', a kind of prophet or oracle of the goddess Amaterasu Omikami, and traveled from Yamato Province, through Iga Province, Omi Province, Mino Province, and Owari Province, arriving in Ise Province, where she is said to have received an oracle to build Ise Jingu Shrine at its present location.

sen.j: 伊勢神宮を建立したときの天照大神から倭姫命への神託は、『日本書紀』垂仁天皇25年春3月丁亥朔丙申条では「是神風伊勢國 則常世之浪重浪歸國也 傍國可怜國也 欲居是國」、『倭姫命世記』では「是神風伊勢國 即常世之浪重浪皈國也 傍國可怜國也 欲居是國」であり、神風（かむかぜ）の伊勢の国は常世の波の敷浪の帰（よ）する国、方国（かたくに）の美まし国なり。この国におらんと欲（おも）ふ と伝えられている。
sen.e: The oracle which was given from Amaterasu Omikami to Yamatohime no Mikoto at time of erecting Ise Jingu Shrine was '是神風伊勢國 則常世之浪重浪歸國也 傍國可怜國也 欲居是國' in article of day of Hinotoi Hinoesaru of March in the spring of twenty-fifth year of Emperor Suinin in "Nihonshoki," and '是神風伊勢國 即常世之浪重浪皈國也 傍國可怜國也 欲居是國' in "Yamatohime no Mikoto Seiki" (articles about Ancient Japan), which both mean Ise Province, where Kamukaze (divine wind) is blowing, is a place where wave of the whole world gathers, and is a beautiful province.

The oracle which Yamatohime no Mikoto received from Amaterasu Omikami at time of erecting Ise Jingu Shrine was recorded as '是神風伊勢國 則常世之浪重浪歸國也 傍國可怜國也 欲居是國' in the article from the day of Hinotoi Hinoesaru of the third month in the spring of the twenty-fifth year of Emperor Suinin's reign in the "Nihonshoki," and as '是神風伊勢國 即常世之浪重浪皈國也 傍國可怜國也 欲居是國' in "Yamatohime no Mikoto Seiki" (Chronicles of Yamatohime no Mikoto), both of which mean 'Ise Province, where the Kamukaze (divine wind) blows, and lapped by waves from all the world, is a beautiful province.

sen.e: It is written in both the Nihon Shoki and "Yamatohime no Mikoto Seiki" (Chronicles of Yamatohime no Mikoto) that when Ise Shrine was erected, Yamatohime no Mikoto was given an oracle by the great sun goddess Amaterasu Omikami that Ise Province, where divine winds blow, is a beautiful place where waves from all around the world lap on its shore and that the goddess will stay in this province forever.

sen.j: 倭姫命は、『三国志』魏志倭人伝にでてくる邪馬台国の畿内説では「卑弥呼」とされることもある。
sen.e: Yamatohime no Mikoto is sometimes regarded as 'Himiko' in theory which assumes that Yamatai-koku Kingdom was located in Kinai Region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara), stated in "Sangokushi" Gishi Wajin Den (the first written record of Japan's commerce).

Yamatohime no Mikoto is sometimes associated with 'Himiko,' who according to the 'Records of Wei, Accounts of the People of Wa', a part of the Chinese 'Records of Three Kingdoms', was the queen of Yamatai-kokuin, near Kyoto.

sen.j: 伊勢神宮鎮座後も倭姫命を祭る神社は存在しなかったが、大正にはいり神宮司庁と地元伊勢市から倭姫命を祭る神社を創建する運動を生じ、1920年1月4日に皇大神宮別宮として倭姫宮の創立が許可、1922年11月5日内宮と外宮の中間である倉田山に鎮座した。
sen.e: There was no shrine dedicated to Yamatohime no Mikoto even after she was enshrined at Ise Jingu Shrine, but after entering Taisho period, a movement to erect shrine to enshrine Yamatohime no Mikoto arose from Jingu Shicho (organization to manage office works of Ise Jingu Shrine) and local Ise City, and on January 4, 1920, permission was given to erect Yamatohime no Miya as Kotai Jingu betsugu (branch shrine of Kotai Jingu), and on November 5, 1922, she was enshrined at Kurata-yama Mountain, located in the middle of Naiku (inner shrine) and Geku (outer shrine).

Even though Yamatohime no Mikoto was enshrined at Ise Jingu Shrine, there was no shrine specifically dedicated to her until the Taisho period, when a movement to erect a shrine to Yamatohime no Mikoto was proposed by Jingu Shicho (the administrative branch of Ise Jingu Shrine) and Ise City, with permission to build Yamatohime no Miya as a branch shrine of Kotai Jingu being granted on January 4, 1920, and on November 5, 1922, she was enshrined at Kurata-yama Mountain, located between the Naiku (inner shrine) and the Geku (outer shrine).

Even after Yamatohime no Mikoto was enshrined at Ise-jingu Shrine, there was no chapel specifically dedicated to her until the Taisho period, when a proposal was made by the administrative branch of Ise-jingu Shrine and Ise City to erect a separate shrine for Yamatohime no Mikoto; the proposal was approved by the government on January 4, 1920 and on November 5, 1922, she was enshrined in Yamatohime no Miya Chapel on Mt. Kurata located between the inner shrine and the outer shrine.

sen.j: 伊勢市倭町に倭姫命を埋葬したと伝えられる古墳があり、伝承に基づき、1928年10月宮内省より陵墓参考地に指定、現在宮内庁により宇治山田陵墓参考地として整備、管理されている。
sen.e: There is a tumulus which is said to have buried Yamatohime no Mikoto in Yamato Town, Ise City, and based on the folklore, it was designated as referable mausoleum by Imperial Household Ministry in October 1928, and it is now maintained and managed as Ujiyamada referable mausoleum by the Imperial Household Ministry.

There is a tumulus where Yamatohime no Mikoto is said to buried in Yamato Town, Ise City, and based on tradition, it was designated a 'reference site' (a term used for tombs believed to be of imperial family members but whose contents are unverifiable) by the Imperial Household Ministry in October 1928, and it is now maintained and managed as Ujiyamada mausoleum reference site by the Imperial Household Agency.
